oai_dc:dc.dc:title: NONSTEADY COMPUTATIONS OF UNDULAR AND BREAKING BORES
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: da Silva, A.F. Teles
Peregrine, D.H.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: bore
breaking bore
undular bore
nonsteady computation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A bore occurs when water with local depth /t1? say, moves over shallower water with depth hi, necessarily moving at a lower speed, in a scale in which horizontal distances are a few times bigger than either h\ or hi- The bore is the region of transition between the two uniform depths and speeds. If the slopes are initially gentle, the bore gets gradually steeper and develops into one of three types depending on the ratio A = hl^hi - For small enough values of A, A ~ 0.7, bore fronts break and the whole bore takes the aspect of a turbulent breaking zone extending over some depths and advancing at a constant speed (over a flat bed); outside this turbulent zone the water is flat. For intermediate values of A breaking and turbulence at the front precede a train of smooth undulations. Here the difference in level between upstream and downstream is fitted partially with breaking and turbulence in the front and partially with undulations, these bores are called undular breaking bores.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 22 (1990): Proceedings of 22nd Conference on Coastal Engineering, Delft, The Netherlands, 1990.
